title: Summer finally arrives for sun-deprived Kiwis
text:
Summer finally arrives for sun-deprived Kiwis Last updated 13:56, February 27 2017 ROSS GIBLIN/FAIRFAX NZ 
Things are looking sunny across the country. Welcome home, summer! 
While the sunny season is almost officially over, it seems the Kiwi summer has finally arrived. 
And the news just keeps getting better, with the sudden rush of summer-like weather expected to continue into the beginning of March. 
MetService meteorologist Lisa Murray said the good weather was set to continue across the country, at least until the end of the week. ALEXANDER RATHS/123RF 
It's time to get in a great Kiwi barbecue - while you still can. 
Murray said we first caught a glimpse of real summery weather on February 9 and 10. 
READ MORE: 
When the South Island experienced its first ridge of high pressure on February 16, it was clear summer had arrived, she said. Seriously great food service and stellar view @batchwinery #waiheke pic.twitter.com/7OnaQi0Zvy â€” Penny Ashton (@pennypink) February 25, 2017 
There was a chance of an Indian Summer, which means a longer, later summer. 
However, long-term forecasts didn't suggest a particularly hot autumn. Though it is hard to accurately predict weather in the long-term. Ad Feedback 
"It's not time to put away the bikinis and the boardies just yet." 
Murray said summer-deprived Wellingtonians should be out making the most of the "perfect barbecue weather" during the next couple of days. 
The capital's 10-day forecast was looking quite promising. While some cloudy periods and the chance of rain are on the cards for later in the week, the sun will be hanging around most days. 
"I highly recommend Wellingtonians get out and enjoy it. That goes for the whole country." 
WeatherWatch said the first day of March would kick off with a large high centred both to the east and west of the country - "putting it firmly in control of New Zealand's weather". 
This would means light winds, sea and lake breezes, and daytime cloud build-ups. This could mean the odd heavy downpour for Waikato and the Bay of Plenty ranges. 
By next week, the South Island looks to lose its good weather, with a cold front moving in. 
But the high will remain over the North Island for a little longer. - Stuff
